author: timbeiko
content:
**ACDE Recap**

**Pectra scoping**
- We agreed to remove EIP-3074 from Pectra in favor of EIP-7702. We'll CFI 7702 for now, include it in the next devnet, and host a breakout room in the next two weeks to finalize the spec. Assuming there is consensus on the final spec by the next ACDE, we'll formally include it in the fork. PR üîú ! 
- We had a lot of conversation about when we should aim to ship Pectra, what features may warrant extending the scope, to what extent it would affect dates, etc. It feels like decisions around PeerDAS inclusion on the CL side are the most significant factor in the "shape" of the update. **CL teams**, please take the time to think through this before ACDC next week, as it would be great to make a decision on the topic then. Assuming we do, we'll finalize the EL side of things on the next ACDE. The EthPandaOps details many options: https://notes.ethereum.org/@ethpandaops/pectra-fork-thoughts

**Candidate EIPs**
- Updates were shared about EOF, with the solidity team and a few EL teams indicating support, while Geth has concerns about the scope/timeline/complexity of the feature. 
- Other EIPs were discussed, without much feedback from client teams: 7623, 7212, and SSZ. See the agenda for the linked updates. 

**Other topics**
- I highlighted the Nyota recap blog post shared earlier
- A proposal to add `returnData` in Transaction Receipts (https://github.com/ethereum/execution-apis/pull/542). No consensus beyond capturing the context from the call's conversation in the form of a better rationale in the PR and continuing the conversation there. 
- The minimum miner tip conversation: after much back and forth, we agreed this should not be standardized across all clients, and Geth is going to keep a non-zero minimum, but evaluate lower options than the current 1 Gwei. 

Lastly, <@364458974906548225> gave a Portal/<#953349957400821860> update: there is an IRL meetup about it next week, please reach out to him if you'd like to join üòÑ !

author: kolbyml
content:
**Quick Portal info based off questions**
Portal is built on the discv5 stack, not devp2p. Portal is a collection of discv5 sub-protocols. Each network can be ran seperately so each Portal sub-network history/state/beacon are minimal.

For the 4444's use we will work on an EIP, but for starters I recommend reading <https://github.com/ethereum/portal-network-specs/blob/master/portal-wire-protocol.md> and <https://github.com/ethereum/portal-network-specs/blob/master/history-network.md>

author: draganrakita
content:
I feel it would be good to have EOF discussion and summary in writing.

Reth, Besu and Erigon want to include EOF in Prague. All of them are fine with q1 2025 fork (from lately called MegaFork or GigaFork).

Reth is okay with both one or two fork options.

Besu expressed that a good target is early 2025 and that two forks would leave more surface area for scope creep and delays.
Besu statement ( post and blog): https://discord.com/channels/595666850260713488/1243235232082301009/1243285089694257336
https://consensys.io/blog/besu-maintainers-on-the-pectra-fork

Erigon doesn't want two forks and in that case, would like to delay EOF after Verkle as they see Verkle as more important.

Geth is of the stance that they want to include it later and think that the inclusion of EOF in Prague will push it for q1 2025 and they dont want to move the fork. They stated it is a good feature and want to include it at some point.

EthJs preference is to have two forks. To keep the current Pectra fork in its current form including  EIP-7702. And the second fork with  EOF, being proposed directly for Q1 2025 (likely end of Q1 though) and not e.g. Q2 to not substantially shift the Verkle fork timeline, even if placed before the Verkle fork.
Blog post: https://notes.ethereum.org/C2xqg0pKRW2TL7WfFqka_Q?view

Nethermind listed two options with three or two forks (The last fork in both options being Verkle). They would like to ship EOF before Verkle, option 1) would have EOF in the second fork while option 2) would be a GigaFork with EOF included.
https://github.com/ethereum/pm/issues/1052#issuecomment-2152417008

Solidity is strongly in favour of EOF, while Vyper supports it ( with the caveats https://discord.com/channels/595666850260713488/745077610685661265/1243241532052602881 ). Alex expressed that ACD dont have good visibility on how people would use EOF and how important it is for them.

EthPandaOps gave an overview and potential fork options and stated they prefer option 2 which is two forks for CL and potentially including EOF in Prague.
Post: https://notes.ethereum.org/@ethpandaops/pectra-fork-thoughts

Timestamps of youtube video, hope I didn't miss something: 
41:30 - 49:40, 1:20:00 - 1:23:00, 1:26:00 - 1:30:00

author: big_tech_sux
content:
vyper is supportive, with the caveat that the spec could be improved as detailed in this eth-magicians thread (https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/evm-object-format-eof/5727/92) specifically around future proofing the format with vlq, and around the design of code sections. i think it wouldn't hurt to have a bit more time to work on the spec. the gas schedule can also be fine tuned.

these aren't showstoppers, it would be OK to ship as is (pending any details that ipsilon team is ironing out). but in a perfect world, we would have more time.

as for prioritization based on how people are using the EVM, i have also been vocal about support for more accessible ways to prevent reentrancy (these include EIPS 5902 PAY opcode, 7609 reduce pricing of transient storage and 7705 NONREENTRANT opcode, i can come up with more proposals if anybody wants üôÇ ).

i think EOF is for sure a quality-of-life improvement and also comes with some execution efficiencies. however, the current state of reentrancy protection is a huge massive security hole for users which has known solutions and can be addressed, it just needs to be prioritized by core devs. i don't think it makes sense to prioritize EOF over one of the above proposals (i favor 5902+7609). that is my personal stance on the matter. if reentrancy protection is more accessible, we can make reentrancy protection the _default_ for users of vyper, i consider this a much bigger win than execution gains from EOF. that doesn't mean we don't like EOF, but if there is prioritization conflict, reentrancy protection and user safety should come first IMO.

(i can write up an official vyper position on this and put it in a more visible location, but it will basically just say the above, which itself is a summary of what i said in the video that dragan linked and my eth-magicians post)

author: rudolf6
content:
Perhaps an obvious meta point around this fork scope discussion, but wondering if we should try to stick a bit more strongly to certain "defaults and exceptions" (in line with how we use CFI & included) 

There's no silver bullet ofc, and we need to make sure we maintain flexibility in the process.. I think most folks agree it's more important to make the *best* decision rather than the *fastest* decision here. But its also a balance. (e.g. losing momentum can have 2nd-order effects). Idea should be sticking to certain defaults that we set helps us to generally make the best decisions as effectively as possible? 

For example: 

default: 
if we have a set of EIPs that get "included" for a specific fork, then the default should be to ship those "included" EIPs before we expand scope. 

exception: 
It is the exception that any EIP: (i) gets *removed* after being "included" (e.g. due to issues found during testing), or (ii) gets *added* at a much later date (e.g. bc progress is made significantly faster than expected, and realize a growing importance of the EIP, like we are seeing now with peerdas)

author: big_tech_sux
content:
yea just to clarify my position (i have already gotten a couple messages about it, maybe bits of it could be taken out of context)
- i have evaluated EOF on its own merits and "cautiously" support it, with the stated caveats
- i don't think EOF and EIP-7609 / 5902 are incompatible.
- *if* there is a scheduling conflict (and for instance i have been told informally  that PAY would be too much scope to include alongside EOF) -- my position is that reentrancy protection should take priority
